perturbation.original_text: 11. PAYMENT: Under Letter of Credit or T/T: Under the Letter of Credit: The Buyer shall open an irrevocable letter of credit with the bank within 30 days after signing the contract, in favor of the Seller, for 100% value of the total contract value. The letter of credit should state that partial shipments are allowed. The Buyer's agent agrees to pay for the goods in accordance with the actual amount of the goods shipped. 80% of the system value being shipped will be paid against the documents stipulated in Clause 12.1. The remaining 20% of the system value being shipped will be paid against the documents stipulated in Clause 12.2. perturbation.changed_text: 11. PAYMENT: Under Letter of Credit or T/T: Under the Letter of Credit: The Buyer shall open a revocable letter of credit with the bank within 30 days after signing the contract, in favor of the Seller, for 100% value of the total contract value. The letter of credit should state that partial shipments are allowed. The Buyer's agent agrees to pay for the goods in accordance with the actual amount of the goods shipped. 80% of the system value being shipped will be paid against the documents stipulated in Clause 12.1. The remaining 20% of the system value being shipped will be paid against the documents stipulated in Clause 12.2. The Letter of Credit shall be valid until 90 days after the latest shipment is effected.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specified an 'irrevocable' letter of credit, providing security to the seller. Changing it to 'revocable' introduces uncertainty and risk for the seller, as the buyer could potentially cancel the letter of credit. The buyer could revoke the line of credit at any moment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code ยง 5-106. REVOCATION, AMENDMENT, CANCELLATION, AND DURATION.
perturbation.law_explanation: Under the UCC, specifically ยง 5-106, the default is that a letter of credit is irrevocable unless explicitly stated otherwise. By changing 'irrevocable' to 'revocable,' the contract goes against the common expectation and understanding in commercial transactions, as the parties need to have a clear understanding of whether the LoC can be revoked or not.

perturbation.original_text: 16. CLAIMS: Within 7 days after the arrival of the goods at destination, should the quality, specification, or quantity be found not in conformity with the stipulations of the Contract except those claims for which the insurance company or the owners of the vessel are liable, the Buyers, on the strength of the Inspection Certificate issued by the China Commodity Inspection Bureau, have the right to claim for replacement with new goods, or for compensation, and all the expenses (such as inspection charges, freight for returning the goods and for sending the replacement, insurance premium, storage and loading and unloading charges etc.) shall be borne by the Sellers. The Certificate so issued shall be accepted as the base of a claim. The Sellers, in accordance with the Buyers' claim, shall be responsible for the immediate elimination of the defect(s), complete or partial replacement of the commodity or shall devaluate the commodity according to the state of defect(s). Where necessary, the Buyers shall be at liberty to eliminate the defect(s) themselves at the Sellers' expenses. If the Sellers fail to answer the Buyers within one weeks after receipt of the aforesaid claim, the claim shall be reckoned as having been accepted by the Sellers.
perturbation.changed_text: 16. CLAIMS: Within 7 days after the arrival of the goods at destination, should the quality, specification, or quantity be found not in conformity with the stipulations of the Contract except those claims for which the insurance company or the owners of the vessel are liable, the Buyers, on the strength of their own assessment, have the right to claim for replacement with new goods, or for compensation, and all the expenses (such as inspection charges, freight for returning the goods and for sending the replacement, insurance premium, storage and loading and unloading charges etc.) shall be borne by the Sellers. The Buyers' assessment shall be accepted as the base of a claim. The Sellers, in accordance with the Buyers' claim, shall be responsible for the immediate elimination of the defect(s), complete or partial replacement of the commodity or shall devaluate the commodity according to the state of defect(s). Where necessary, the Buyers shall be at liberty to eliminate the defect(s) themselves at the Sellers' expenses. If the Sellers fail to answer the Buyers within one weeks after receipt of the aforesaid claim, the claim shall be reckoned as having been accepted by the Sellers.
perturbation.explanation: The original text required an Inspection Certificate issued by the China Commodity Inspection Bureau to validate claims. This provides an objective, third-party assessment. The modified version allows the Buyers' own assessment to be the basis of a claim, which creates a conflict of interest and removes the objectivity in determining quality issues.
perturbation.contradicted_law: United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (CISG), Article 38
perturbation.law_explanation: Article 38 of the CISG requires the buyer to examine the goods or cause them to be examined, within as short a period as is practicable in the circumstances. By allowing the buyer's assessment to be the sole basis for a claim without requiring an objective inspection, the modified text undermines the obligation to conduct a proper examination and could violate internationally agreed principles for sales contract claim processes.

perturbation.original_text: 17. FORCE MAJEURE: The Sellers shall not be held responsible for the delay in shipment or non-delivery, of the goods due to Force Majeure, which might occur during the process of manufacturing or in the course of loading or transit. The Sellers shall advise the Buyers immediately of the occurrence mentioned above and within fourteen days thereafter, the Sellers shall send by airmail to the Buyers a certificate of the accident issued by the competent government authorities, Chamber of Commerce or registered notary public of the place where the accident occurs as evidence thereof. Under such circumstances the Sellers, however, are still under the obligation to take all necessary measures to hasten the delivery of the goods. In case the accident lasts for more than 10 weeks, the Buyers shall have the right to cancel the Contract.
perturbation.changed_text: 17. FORCE MAJEURE: The Sellers shall not be held responsible for the delay in shipment or non-delivery, of the goods due to Force Majeure, which might occur during the process of manufacturing or in the course of loading or transit. The Sellers shall advise the Buyers immediately of the occurrence mentioned above; however, any certificate of the accident is optional. Under such circumstances the Sellers, however, are still under the obligation to take all necessary measures to hasten the delivery of the goods. In case the accident lasts for more than 10 weeks, the Buyers shall have the right to cancel the Contract.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause explicitly required the seller to provide a certificate from a recognized authority (government, chamber of commerce, notary public) as evidence of a force majeure event. By stating that such a certificate is 'optional,' the burden of proof for a force majeure event is significantly weakened, going against standard legal practice for claiming force majeure.
perturbation.contradicted_law: United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (CISG), Article 79
perturbation.law_explanation: Article 79 of the CISG requires a party to prove that the failure to perform was due to an impediment beyond their control and that they could not reasonably have avoided or overcome the impediment. Removing the requirement for a certificate from a recognized authority makes it more difficult to establish this proof, as the party could claim force majeure without providing sufficient evidence.
